Because he's wrong. Finals are pretty much always left vs right on the bracket, not top vs bottom.

No it hasn't.
[Here](http://www.ncaa.com/march-madness-live/bracket) is the current official NCAA bracket. In the semifinals the East Region's champion will play with West Region's champion and the Midwest Region's champion will play with South Region's champion, since the the number one overall seed (Villanova) was in the East and the number four overall seed (Gonzaga) is in the West. Left vs Right, not Top vs Bottom.

The Americans isn't FX's worst-rated show; this season it's 8th out of 15 in viewers and 10th out of 15 in the 18-49 demo (FX's current lowest-rated show is Sex Drugs Rock Roll, which they cancelled). NBC just loves cancelling well-made shows and replacing them with shit.
NBC loves cancelling shows with shit ratings and replacing them with shows they hope won't have shit ratings. But they renewed Hannibal twice despite its shit ratings, and for that you should be thankful.
Seeing as ratings translate directly into revenue for the network and the network is a business, yeah, renewing their worst-rated show was arguably rather generous.

Hannibal was NBC's worst-rated show in its second season and they renewed it anyway, which is far more generous than networks usually are. You should be thankful that you got even 3 seasons of Hannibal given how bad its viewership was.
If you're mad about Hannibal getting cancelled blame all the people who didn't watch it, not NBC who gave it a third season in spite of its abysmal ratings.

There are lots of fiscally irresponsible people, and dealing with a big lump-sum income isn't something most people are really prepared for. Most lottery winners go broke within a few years.

I'm not at all surprised that people are still willing to do it; plenty of people would probably have been willing to do it for less than 1 million originally, but $1 million made for a nicer round number. $1 million is still a huge sum for most people, and it's only a 30% decrease in real terms compared to 17 years ago.

But Knights weren't common soldiers, they were a rank of nobility. Men who would become Knights generally did start training as children.

Wrestling was a very important skill for a knight. Fighting in full plate armor would often involved wresting moves because of how much the armor limited the effectiveness of most weapons (for instance armored longsword fencing was arguably closer to 'wresting with swords' than to modern fencing).

Does the Knight's rigorous adherence to his battle etiquette get in the way of his being able to preform if the Marine decides to play dirty?
The knights' "rigorous adherence to his battle etiquette" wasn't really a thing. Knights fought to win and had no problem with fighting dirty.

But why use the price at which you bought a stock as the denominator in the yield calculation rather than the current value? That's not the way yield is typically calculated, and doesn't really do anything aside from conflating price appreciation and actual dividend yield. Saying that different people simultaneously get different yields on the same stock simply because the purchased it at different times makes little sense.

Now, you have $0.75/share dividend, which when compared to your initial $10 purchase price yields 7.5%.
How is (current dividend)/(price from years ago) a useful metric?

No, it's pretty bad; OP didn't seem to realize that a convertible bond is not the same thing as a warrant.

OP's math assumes Tesla is selling warrants, but they're actually selling convertible bonds. So OP effectively forgot to account for things like interest payments and repayment of principal; the analysis is worthless.

[tvseriesfinale](http://tvseriesfinale.com) is a good source for ratings.
This season of TWD is averaging a 5.5 in the 18-49 demo (Live+SD), with its most recent episode getting a 4.7. That's the best on AMC by a huge amount ([source](http://tvseriesfinale.com/tv-show/amc-network-tv-show-ratings-33643/)) and easily better than any other current cable show (Game of Thrones will likely be close once its its next season comes out as it averaged a [3.85](http://tvseriesfinale.com/tv-show/hbo-tv-show-ratings-33447/) last season). It's also better than any show on the major broadcast networks ([ABC](http://tvseriesfinale.com/tv-show/abc-tv-show-2016-2017-season-ratings/), [CBS](http://tvseriesfinale.com/tv-show/cbs-tv-show-2016-2017-season-ratings/), [Fox](http://tvseriesfinale.com/tv-show/fox-tv-show-2016-2017-season-ratings/), [NBC](http://tvseriesfinale.com/tv-show/nbc-tv-show-2016-2017-season-ratings/)). If you looks at the ratings for other networks you'll see that nothing tops TWD and very few shows are even close.
It terms of overall viewership it's also top on cable by quite a bit, but there are a few broadcast shows that beat it in that metric.

If you're trying to sort by date then YYYY/MM/DD (or an equivalent such as YYYY-MM-DD) is the best format to use, by far. It puts the most significant digit on the left and the lest significant on the right, just as with numbers. YYYY-MM-DD is the format typically used in computing currently.
He usually does the Tour de Romandie and Volta a Catalunya as well.

If you're going to shit on Lance at least don't be completely ignorant about it (it's not like there aren't plenty of legitimate reasons to shit on him).
Lance was not a nobody prior to 1997. He wasn't a star youth cyclist because he didn't switch to cycling until he was 20; prior to that he was a two-time national champion triathlete. In his second year as a pro cyclist he won the world championships; from 1992 to 1996 he also won the Fleche Wallone, two stages of the TDF, San Sebastin, and had second-place finishes in LigeBastogneLige (twice), Paris-Nice, and San Sebastin. Oh and he finished the 1995 TDF in 36th place.
As far as doping goes I don't see how comparing Lance to Pantani means anything; Pantani was doping just as hard as Lance (multiple retroactive positive tests for EPO from the 1998 Tour, got thrown out of the 1999 Giro for having 50% hemocrit, etc).
